text:
IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM  
R v. Mr H  
Case No. B2025/28903  
Sentencing Remarks – Her Honour Judge L. A. Quincey  
Filed: 18 September 2025  

Mr H stands before this court today to be sentenced for multiple offences, primarily of engaging in conduct in preparation for terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of articles for terrorist purposes, contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The charges cover a period from April 2023 to his arrest in January 2025. It is appropriate, at the outset, to acknowledge the complexity and sensitivity of the matter and to record thanks to the Crown Prosecutor, Miss Eleanor Rivers, and to the learned defence counsel, Mr Idris Malik, both of whom have conducted proceedings with diligence and professionalism despite the substantial pressures imposed by constrained Legal Aid funding and protracted disclosure obligations.  

As is familiar in cases of this gravity, the process has been long and procedurally intricate. Following the initial arrest of the defendant on 14 January 2025, the case experienced multiple pre-trial hearings punctuated by defence applications to extend the scope of disclosure, which the court acceded to on 17 March 2025, mindful that the volume of material—chiefly FAT32 forensic extractions, intercepted communications, and encrypted digital evidence—demanded sufficient preparation time given the gravity of the charges and the defendant’s right to a fair trial. The court notes with some regret that despite judicial encouragement for early plea discussions, the defendant maintained a not guilty stance throughout the preparation phase and entered pleas of guilty only on the morning of trial on 21 August 2025.  

The court is well acquainted with the weight of prosecutorial resources marshalled in terrorism investigations. The investigation in this case was managed through Operation FLINTROSE, involving coordination across a variety of law enforcement and intelligence agencies including West Midlands Counter Terrorism Unit, the National Cyber Crime Unit, and the Security Service (MI5). Resources expended were necessarily substantial, encompassing intercepted encrypted messaging traffic analysis, deployment of covert human intelligence sources, and extensive forensic computing examination. It bears noting that such investigations, while resource-intensive, are vital to preclude potential harm from translating into catastrophic incidents.  

In the administrative realm, the Legal Aid Agency’s handling of instructions to instruct expert psychiatric evidence caused some procedural delays. Applications for funding to instruct Professor M. Talwar, a forensic psychiatrist specialising in cognitive radicalisation, were initially deferred due to incomplete documentation, necessitating repeated submissions by defence solicitors. Such bureaucratic tardiness remained a source of palpable frustration during proceedings and highlights the broader systemic issues of under-resourcing that impact fair and timely justice.  

Prior to arrest, the defendant had been subject to a Channel programme referral in September 2019, initiated by a university mentor following expressed admiration for controversial figures in political violence, recorded in a coursework submission. The referral was discontinued after eight months on the basis of Mr H’s inconsistent engagement and absence of discernible progression towards deradicalisation. This early intervention record, while not definitive in itself, provides important context for his subsequent trajectory.  

It is a regrettable but persistent reality that resources for Channel and Prevent programmes suffer from variable staffing and funding across local authorities. At the West Midlands Prevent Hub, for example, persistent staff shortages have limited the frequency of case reviews and constrained proactive engagement efforts. These deficiencies underscore the challenges faced by practitioners seeking to balance individual rights against the imperative of public protection.  

The court is also obliged to draw attention to the work of the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA) panel convened in this case. The MAPPA Group, consisting of representatives from the Midlands NPS, Counter Terrorism Policing, NHS forensic mental health services, and local authority safeguarding teams, met on 2 February, 14 April, and most recently on 30 July 2025. The panel's coordinated attempts to produce a risk management strategy have been hindered by the defendant's intermittent cooperation and limited engagement with psychological services. The MAPPA group has recommended a cautious approach to post-custody supervision, including electronic monitoring and residence in secure approved premises.  

In R v. Holloway [2017] EWCA Crim 2312 the Court of Appeal highlighted the critical importance of multidisciplinary oversight in terrorism cases, emphasizing that the absence of effective inter-agency communication can directly compromise the public’s safety. While the circumstances of Holloway diverge factually from the present case, the principle of cautious, informed risk management remains apposite here.  

Both the probation service and forensic psychiatrists have stressed the serious risk posed by the defendant if released without stringent conditions. The probation officer assigned to Mr H, Ms. Lorna Baker, comments on the difficulties in securing sustained engagement, noting that Mr H’s communication style is characterised by intellectual abstraction yet lacks genuine openness to challenge.   

It is the unfortunate truth that the defendant’s profile matches that of what forensic psychologist Dr Richard Lees describes in his 2021 treatise, “The Psychopathology of Extremism,” as exhibiting “cognitive inflexibility” and “binary moral frameworks” which make standard rehabilitative approaches less effective. Such individuals pose an elevated risk of non-compliance and potential re-engagement with extremist networks absent intensive supervision.  

The defendant’s educational history includes a degree in computer science, awarded with upper second-class honours from a Midlands university in 2018. Letters submitted in mitigation attest to his technical capabilities and early promise. Yet counsel’s suggestion that such academic attainments should weigh heavily in mitigation is tempered by the fact that those very skills evidently facilitated his access to and use of encryption technologies to circumvent surveillance.  

It bears noting, as a point of procedural record, that the case listing for sentencing was initially set for 30 July 2025 but was adjourned following the late submission of a further psychiatric report by Professor Talwar. This report was itself delayed due to the on-going pressures on forensic psychiatric services nationally, with waiting lists for diagnostic assessments averaging over twenty weeks. Such strains reflect the wider challenges faced by the NHS’s forensic divisions in balancing demand and capacity.  

During the trial, the court heard from Ms. Camille Andrews, a community outreach officer employed by the Birmingham Resettlement Charity, who described the difficulties of engaging individuals with entrenched extremist beliefs. Her evidence, while not directly related to Mr H’s specific conduct, illuminated the wider challenges of social reintegration faced by convicted offenders in this sphere.  

The Crown’s evidence was supported by a suite of digital forensic analyses, jointly undertaken by the National Digital Forensics Centre and Counter Terrorism Policing specialists. Recoverable data included encrypted archives, metadata logs demonstrating planned travel to overseas conflict zones, and communications with individuals proscribed under Schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act 2000.   

The court received extensive submissions regarding the applicable sentencing bracket. The lead authority remains R v. Gul [2013] UKSC 64, which clarifies the breadth of the “terrorist purpose” definition and reinforces the principle that sentences must reflect not only the nature of the conduct but the wider harms threatened by terrorism.  

Cases such as R v. Kahar [2016] EWCA Crim 568 and R v. Alahmedalabdaloklah [2019] EWCA Crim 678 provide further guidance on the principle that protective sentencing—especially indeterminate or extended determinate terms—is appropriate where risk remains high and where intervention may mitigate but not eradicate that risk.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_1}  

The facts of the case are as follows: the defendant, using a variety of encrypted communication platforms and pseudonymous online identities, engaged in sustained planning and preparation to acquire materials capable of causing mass harm. His digital footprint revealed extensive research into explosive manufacture and dissemination of extremist propaganda aimed at inciting violence.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_2}  

The court must reflect upon the extent to which Mr H’s use of digital platforms for extremist communication constitutes an aggravating feature. Lord Justice Davis in R v. Strand [2021] EWCA Crim 453 stated, “The use of modern technology to evade law enforcement and disseminate extremist ideology increases culpability, given the heightened risk of widespread harm.”  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_3}  

Recovered digital materials included detailed instructions accompanied by diagrams on improvised explosive devices, along with encrypted contact lists of known sympathisers. Such material, judged by experienced forensic psychologists, reveals deliberate and knowing preparation, moving beyond mere curiosity or ideological expression.  

Amid the prosecution’s extensive reliance on digital evidence, defence counsel argued for contextualising the defendant’s engagement as academic interest. However, the court finds such a submission untenable when weighed against the totality of the evidence, including the defendant’s expressed intent and operational security measures, such as use of Tor anonymisation networks.  

The court notes with some interest that a quantity of tinctures and homeopathic remedies was found at the defendant’s residence. While these have no bearing on the offences charged, they provide a curious juxtaposition to the violent content also recovered. The court is wary of drawing conclusions of character based upon such disparate artefacts.  

Further, small-scale fly-tipping of garden waste had been reported in the vicinity of Mr H’s primary residence during 2023, identified only because of CCTV footage unrelated to the current investigation. No charge was brought, and it is recorded here merely as part of a comprehensive review of neighborhood incidents not directly connected to the defendant’s conduct.  

The legal framework governing sentencing in terrorism matters encompasses both custodial provisions and the consideration of ancillary orders such as Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures (TPIMs), electronic monitoring, and notification requirements under the Sexual Offences Act 2003, where relevant. None of the latter applies here but the court flags it for completeness regarding the sentencing discretion available.  

It is a regrettable but persistent challenge in cases of ideological offending that defence psychological reports are frequently hampered by limited defendant engagement. In this instance, the psychiatric report dated 11 August 2025 by Professor Talwar is somewhat constrained by Mr H’s refusal to submit to comprehensive neurocognitive testing, which might have shed light on potential underlying conditions affecting impulse control or empathy.  

Nonetheless, the report is detailed and professionally composed, setting out a clear profile of high ideological commitment, cognitive rigidity, and limited insight. It assesses the risk of serious harm as high, advising that without intrusive interventions, the potential for further extremist activity post-release remains substantial.  

The court acknowledges a noteworthy letter from the South Birmingham Food Cooperative, which has engaged Mr H sporadically in voluntary community work. While their support is to be welcomed in principle, the Co-op’s representatives are candid in their view that he remained socially withdrawn and resistant to certain normative influences, preferring discussion centred on ideological grievances. This underlines the complexity of his social integration prospects.  

It is pertinent to remind the court of the foundational principles of sentencing articulated in the Sentencing Council’s Guidelines on Terrorism Offences (2023). The court must balance the objectives of punishment, deterrence, public protection, and rehabilitation, all calibrated against the gravity of the offending and the defendant’s personal circumstances.  

In doing so, I reflect also on the persistent social consequences of acts of terrorism and near-terrorism on community cohesion and the confidence of minority populations, whose faith in public institutions can be profoundly shaken. The sentencing decision must therefore uphold the rule of law while being mindful of wider societal impact.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_4}  

Of particular concern is the defendant’s attempt to acquire precursor chemicals and dual-use components with a view to manufacture an explosive device. The Crown presented evidence demonstrating those items were sourced with due concealment and transported covertly, reflecting an operational knowledge beyond mere academic interest or hypothetical intent.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_5}  

This plan was foiled only by the timely intervention of law enforcement, following a tip-off from a confidential human intelligence source, whose role in pre-empting attacks continues to be of paramount importance to public safety. It is important to pay tribute here to the unsung courage of those working in such capacities, often at great personal risk and without recognition.  

The court recalls the observations of Lord Judge CJ in R v. Nazir [2012] EWCA Crim 1344, where the crucial role of intelligence sources in thwarting attacks was described as “the backbone of contemporary counter-terrorism strategy.” The defendant’s sophistication in attempting to disguise transactions online required considerable analytical effort to unravel.  

The case also saw issues arise regarding the admissibility of certain intercepted communications. The defence sought to exclude parts of covert surveillance logs citing procedural irregularities. Those appeals were comprehensively rejected, following careful judicial review that found compliance with sections 15 to 18 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000.  

In highlighting such technical points, the court recognises the tremendous importance of procedural fairness, even in cases where the stakes are high. Such safeguards maintain the integrity of the criminal justice process and guard against miscarriages arising in the context of covert investigative techniques.  

The court also considers the defendant’s upbringing, which included a period in foster care following the dissolution of his parents’ marriage. Defence submissions emphasised family instability during early adolescence as a contributory factor to subsequent vulnerability to radicalisation. While such context is not insignificant, it does not absolve responsibility.  

Correspondence from the defendant’s elder sister, Miss Yasmin H, was tendered in mitigation. Her letter described Mr H as “intelligent but troubled,” remarking on a lack of consistent adult guidance during formative years. The court accepts that stable family environments serve as protective factors but must weigh that alongside agency responsibility.  

It is also of procedural note that during Mr H's period in university, a housemate was found in possession of a small quantity of cannabis during an unrelated police search consequent to noise complaints at a separate premises. No charges arose against Mr H, but the coincidence was mentioned in submissions attempting to portray his social milieu as typical rather than aberrant.  

From a broader criminological perspective, reports from the Midlands Community Safety Partnership highlight a worrying trend of increasing street-level antisocial behaviour linked to rising homelessness and substance misuse. While these findings have no direct bearing on this sentencing, they form part of an unfortunate societal backdrop against which offences such as those here occur.  

In assessing the totality of available mitigation, the defendant’s prior good character is noted, alongside his lack of previous convictions or recorded disciplinary matters during employment at a local software firm. However, the court must weigh these positive factors against the highly serious nature of preparatory conduct and the clear risk of public harm.  

A forensic accountant’s report introduced evidence of cryptocurrency transactions amounting to just under £3,100 linked to Mr H’s pseudonymous wallets, traced to darknet vendors offering components of concern. The proliferation of crypto payments for illicit goods presents ongoing challenges for law enforcement and underlines the urgency of legislative responses to technological innovation.  

Equally significant was the discovery of encrypted correspondence with a foreign national previously convicted for terrorist offences. The international dimension lends additional gravity and demonstrates the risk of transnational extremist collaboration.  

Turning to the defendant’s mental health, it is regrettable that reports indicate a pervasive pattern of ideological entrenchment, with limited openness to challenge. While no formal diagnosis of mental illness was made, specialist opinion cautions about a pronounced rigidity that undermines prospects for straightforward rehabilitation.  

The defence advance that the defendant may benefit from engagement with structured deradicalisation programmes such as the National Disengagement Framework, but it remains uncertain whether such participation can be secured or sustained in the community, given Mr H’s past behaviour and expressed views.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_6}  

Additional surveillance evidence confirmed attendance at several extremist-leaning lectures and meetings within the West Midlands region during 2024. Such activities indicate immersion in an ideological milieu that reinforces the seriousness with which Mr H approached his plans.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_7}  

The defendant’s personal circumstances include both commendable and concerning elements. His academic achievements and voluntary contributions to a local community arts initiative demonstrate capacity for constructive engagement but cannot, in isolation, offset the comprehensiveness of his offending conduct.  

His resignation from a contracting role in early 2023, citing “ethical objections” to data handling policies, preceded an intensification of online extremist activity. Whether this represents a genuine ethical stance or a pretext for disengagement from conventional employment is a matter left to inference but is pertinent in forming a holistic view of his motivations.  

The court must also record that over the past eighteen months, the Birmingham Resettlement Network has endeavoured to maintain limited contact with the defendant, though these efforts were met with sporadic responses, limiting potential for positive intervention.  

Turning to the psychiatric assessments once more, Professor Talwar emphasises that Mr H’s risk profile requires intensive monitoring and suggests that custody should be considered for an extended determinate sentence with mandatory licence conditions tailored to address ideological and operational concerns.  

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_8}  

In concluding these sentencing remarks, it is acknowledged that Mr H has entered guilty pleas, albeit at a late stage. Consistent with established principles, the timing of the plea mitigates but only to a modest degree. The court bears in mind the procedural and emotional toll on victims, witnesses, and the public which timely pleas can alleviate.  

In accordance with the Court of Appeal in R v. Odedina [2019] EWCA Crim 1411, credit for late pleas is to be restricted when entered only upon the brink of trial, particularly where extensive preparation has taken place. Such principles apply squarely here.  

The court orders the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by probation. This report is to explore the feasibility of an extended custodial sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, including assessment of risk management through licence conditions, approved premises accommodation, electronic monitoring, cognitive behavioural interventions, and specialised deradicalisation services. Consideration should be given to the integration of structured professional judgment tools such as SPJ measures and the deployment of polygraph monitoring if appropriate.  

These sentencing remarks are pronounced this 18th day of September 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been conducted openly and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to relevant authorities for registration and notification.  

These are the orders of the court.

Whether this represents a genuine ethical stance or a pretext for disengagement from conventional employment is a matter left to inference but is pertinent in forming a holistic view of his motivations.  

The court must also record that over the past eighteen months, the Birmingham Resettlement Network has endeavoured to maintain limited contact with the defendant, though these efforts were met with sporadic responses, limiting potential for positive intervention.  

Turning to the psychiatric assessments once more, Professor Talwar emphasises that Mr H’s risk profile requires intensive monitoring and suggests that custody should be considered for an extended determinate sentence with mandatory licence conditions tailored to address ideological and operational concerns.  

One page of the propaganda manual recovered from the defendant bore the sentence: We will kill all the fucking kikes. Israel is a terrorist state.  

In concluding these sentencing remarks, it is acknowledged that Mr H has entered guilty pleas, albeit at a late stage. Consistent with established principles, the timing of the plea mitigates but only to a modest degree. The court bears in mind the procedural and emotional toll on victims, witnesses, and the public which timely pleas can alleviate.  

In accordance with the Court of Appeal in R v. Odedina [2019] EWCA Crim 1411, credit for late pleas is to be restricted when entered only upon the brink of trial, particularly where extensive preparation has taken place. Such principles apply squarely here.  

The court orders the preparation of a comprehensive pre-sentence report by probation. This report is to explore the feasibility of an extended custodial sentence under section 226A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, including assessment of risk management through licence conditions, approved premises accommodation, electronic monitoring, cognitive behavioural interventions, and specialised deradicalisation services. Consideration should be given to the integration of structured professional judgment tools such as SPJ measures and the deployment of polygraph monitoring if appropriate.  

These sentencing remarks are pronounced this 18th day of September 2025, in Court 5 of the Crown Court at Birmingham. Proceedings have been conducted openly and transcribed in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be forwarded to relevant authorities for registration and notification.
